title: How may I file bankruptcy? I am still legally married to my husband but we have separated more than 20 years ago.
question: There has been no communication whatsoever for over 20 years. I don't know his whereabouts. I am not even sure if he is still alive. I intend to file Chapter 7 and I learned that a married person who files bankruptcy without the other spouse must file a document called Spousal Waiver of Exemption which should be signed by the nonfiling spouse. How may I do this? Will the document even be required considering my situation? We have no children. We do not have any assets which were acquired while we were still together.
answers:
I'm a bit late, and I believe the other attorneys have answered it thoroughly.

I'm posting only to expand on this thing called "community property," which came up a few times in the responses. I feel like you and other readers might benefit from a quick explanation of it, although you seem to have an instinct for it, so I could be telling you something you already know.

In California, and other Western states, we use a legal system called "community property." As I understand it, it's actually a tradition picked up from when the states were under Spanish rule, although I think Louisiana uses it too. Anyway, the idea is that the majority of assets earned or acquired while you are married usually belong to the community, as well as any pre-marriage separate assets that you "contribute" to the community. So those community assets have to be dealt with in a divorce, a bankruptcy proceeding, and other legal proceedings.

However, anything you acquire after you're separated (with some complexities) is your own property (and debt)--not the community's anymore. I noticed you said, "we do not have any assets which were acquired while we were still together," so you seem to understand or have a good instinct for what's going on.

Given the long separation and the fact that you've long since lost touch, even if someone in your situation did have some community assets at one time, they are likely long gone or not worth thinking about. And in any event, spouses who are married can still file individually, although it can get complicated when they aren't or are only recently separated.

Best of luck to you!
Good information has previously provided by my colleagues. Seek further guidance from an experienced bankruptcy attorney in your area to assist you with the filing.

I agree with the prior lawyers. The main thing is that based on what you said there is no community property so you can file an individual petition and then show in your schedules that there is no community property in the bankruptcy estate that would necessitate a spousal waiver.

Atty Espada is correct. Remember, BK is more than checking boxes on forms you find online. Find/consult/hire a lawyer in your area using the Avvo feature "Find a Lawyer". Make a list of 4-5 having many 5 star reviews from satisfied clients. If you don't get a prompt call back from one, go on to the next on your list. Some offer a free consultation by phone or in person.

If you are separated and do not have contact with your spouse, you can file a chapter 7 case as an individual, without any input from your spouse.

The Spousal Waiver of Exemption is designed to protect a person whose spouse files, and there is jointly owned property (aka community property) that may become part of the bankruptcy estate. If no community property is listed in the schedules, the trustee would have no reason to insist on the waiver.

Discuss with a bankruptcy attorney to get more details about how the process will work in your situation.
